questions.Q: Two bodies of mass $$m=1\,\text{kg}$$ and $$M=2\,\text{kg}$$ are connected by a light inextensible string which passes through a smooth fixed pulley. If the fricction is neglected, the tension of the string is:
questions.E: The forces acting upon each body are displayed in the diagram. After applying the Newton's second law to each body we have: $$T=ma$$ and $$Mg-T=Ma$$. From these equations it follows that $$T=\frac{mM}{m+M}g=\frac{(1\,\text{kg})(2\,\text{kg})}{1\,\text{kg}+2\,\text{kg}}g=\frac{2}{3}\,\text{kg}\times 9,8\,\text{m/s}^2=6.5\,\text{N}$$.

questions.Q: Two bodies of mass $$m=1\,\text{kg}$$ and $$M=2\,\text{kg}$$ are connected by a light inextensible string which passes through smooth fixed pulleys. If the fricction is neglected, the tension of the string is:
questions.E: The forces acting upon each body are displayed in the diagram. After applying the Newton's second law to each body we have: $$T-mg=ma$$ and $$Mg-T=Ma$$. From these equations it follows that $$T=\frac{2mM}{m+M}g=\frac{2(1\,\text{kg})(2\,\text{kg})}{1\,\text{kg}+2\,\text{kg}}g=\frac{4}{3}\,\text{kg}\times 9,8\,\text{m/s}^2=13.1\,\text{N}$$.

questions.Q: Two bodies of mass $$m=1\,\text{kg}$$ and $$M=2\,\text{kg}$$ are connected by a light inextensible string which passes through a smooth fixed pulley. If the fricction is neglected and $$\beta=30^{\circ}$$, the acceleration of the $$2\,\text{kg}$$ body is:
questions.E: The forces acting upon each body are displayed in the diagram. After taking the x- components of the forces and applying the Newton's second law to each body it follows that: $$T-mg\sin\beta=ma$$ and $$Mg\sin\beta-T=Ma$$. From these equations it follows that $$a=\frac{M-m}{m+M}g\sin\beta=\frac{2\,\text{kg}-1\,\text{kg}}{1\,\text{kg}+2\,\text{kg}}g\sin(30^{\circ})=\frac{1}{6}g$$.

questions.Q: Two bodies of mass $$m=1\,\text{kg}$$ and $$M=2\,\text{kg}$$ are connected by a light inextensible string which passes through a smooth fixed pulley. If the fricction is neglected and $$\beta=30^{\circ}$$, the acceleration of the $$2\,\text{kg}$$ body is:
questions.E: The forces acting upon each body are displayed in the diagram. After taking the x- components of the forces and applying the Newton's second law to each body it follows that: $$T-mg\sin\beta=ma$$ and $$Mg-T=Ma$$. From these equations it follows that $$a=\frac{(M-m\sin\beta)g}{m+M}= =\frac{(2\,\text{kg}-1\,\text{kg}\sin30^{\circ})(9.8\,\text{m/s}^2))}{1\,\text{kg}+2\,\text{kg}}= 4.9\,\text{m/s}^2$$.

questions.Q: Two bodies of mass $$m=1\,\text{kg}$$ and $$M=2\,\text{kg}$$ are connected by a light inextensible string which passes through a smooth fixed pulley. If the fricction is neglected and $$\alpha=30^{\circ}$$ and the angles of the double inclined plane are $$\alpha=30^{\circ}$$ and $$\beta=45^{\circ}$$, the acceleration of the $$2\,\text{kg}$$ body is:
questions.E: The forces acting upon each body are displayed in the diagram. After taking the x- components of the forces and applying the Newton's second law to each body it follows that: $$T-mg\sin\alpha=ma$$ and $$Mg\sin\beta-T=Ma$$. From these equations it follows that $$a=\frac{(M\sin\beta-m\sin\alpha)g}{m+M}= =\frac{(2\,\text{kg}\sin45^{\circ}-1\,\text{kg}\sin30^{\circ})(9.8\,\text{m/s}^2))}{1\,\text{kg}+2\,\text{kg}}= 0.96\,\text{m/s}^2$$.

questions.Q: In the figure shown, the masses of the bodies are $$m_1=1\,\text{kg}$$,$$m_2=2\,\text{kg}$$ and $$m_0=3\,\text{kg}$$, the strings have negligible mass and the friction is neglected. The tension of the string connecting $$m_1$$ and $$m_2$$ is:
questions.E: The forces acting upon each body are displayed in the diagram. After taking the x- components of the forces and applying the Newton's second law to each body it follows that: $$T_1=m_1a$$,  $$T-T_1=m_2a$$ and $$m_0g-T=m_0a$$. From these equations it follows that $$a=\frac{m_0g}{m_1+m_2+m_0}=\frac{(3\,\text{kg})(9.8\,\text{m/s}^2)}{1\,\text{kg}+2\,\text{kg}+3\,\text{kg}}=4.9\,\text{m/s}^2$$. Thus, tension $$T_1=m_1a_1=(1\,\text{kg})(4.9\,\text{m/s}^2)=4.9\,\text{N}$$
